Award.AwardTitle: Modulation of Macro and Micro Mechanics of ECM by DDR1

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to use a combination of biophysical and computational tools to investigate the mechanics of the extracellular matrix (ECM) and how it is modified by proteins secreted by the cells. The ECM in most vertebrate tissue is composed primarily of collagen type 1 fibers. The structure of collagen fibers can be modulated by a number of collagen binding proteins. The proposed studies will evaluate the effect of such ultra-structural modifications in collagen fibers on the mechanical properties of the 3D matrix and on cell-matrix interactions at the macro and micro-scale levels using optical tweezers, uniaxial testing and gel contraction. In parallel, a multi-scale computational model will be developed to model the global and local mechanical responses of the collagen fiber matrix to uniaxial stress and traction forces exerted by the cells.

If successful, these studies will provide novel insights into how naturally-induced alterations in the collagen ultra-structure can affect matrix mechanics, cell-matrix interaction and mechano-transduction. These results will impact the biophysics, biomechanics, biomaterials, and tissue engineering communities. The proposed activities will also develop novel methodologies for experimental and computational studies of the ECM. The educational plan will train two PhD-level graduate students with a diverse set of knowledge and hands-on skills in cell and matrix biology, microscopy, mechanical testing, instrument design, modeling and simulation, thus preparing them to meet the upcoming scientific challenges and tackle complex problems at the interface of engineering and biology. A new workshop on biomechanics is planned for middle school girls.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The environment (matrix) around the cells in our solid tissues is composed of a network of filamentous proteins such as collagen, which is responsible for the mechanical strength of the underlying tissue. A number of factors including the presence of certain naturally occurring matrix proteins can alter the structure of collagen fibrils and its network formation. This project has evaluated how alteration of the collagen network structure alters its mechanical properties at the micro- and macro-scale and its effect on the cell-matrix composite. Two naturally occurring matrix proteins (decoron and discoidin domain receptor 2: DDR2) were used to modulate in-vitro formed collagen networks (gels). Structural alterations in the collagen network were verified by using microscopy techniques. The micro-mechanical properties of collagen gels formed were evaluated using active one particle (1P) and a novel active (2P) micro-rheology techniques and macro-rheology. Both decoron and DDR2 increased the micro-moduli, and mechanical heterogeneity of the collagen gels. However, cell-mediated gel contraction was inhibited by the presence of decoron but enhanced by the presence of DDR2 in the collagen network. Strain-dependent macro-rheology measurements were used to explain these anomalous effects. We thus elucidate how matrix proteins can modulate the mechanical properties of collagen networks in multi-faceted ways. Our study also advanced basic knowledge of DDR-collagen interactions by (i) examining the role of DDR1 and DDR2 oligomerization in interaction with collagen and (ii) elucidating how the collagen fibril structure is altered in-vivo in a mouse lacking DDR1, which could impact the mechanical properties of the underlying tissue.

As a fundamental advancement we developed the 2P active micro-rheology technique using single beam optical tweezer instrumentation. The basic idea of 1P micro-rheology is to oscillate (drive) a bead trapped in a gel using optical tweezers and monitor its displacement to ascertain the micro-rheological properties of the material in the vicinity of the bead. In 2P active micro-rheology we also monitor the displacement of non-driven satellite beads (several microns away) to ascertain the coarse-grained micro-rheological properties of the material between the two beads. Using polyacrylamide as a model material we investigated how 2P active micro-rheology can be used to ascertain parameters like storage moduli, Poisson’s ratio, heterogeneity and anisotropy in the material. We establish how 2P technique is not impacted by bead-matrix coupling effects commonly seen in 1P micro-rheology. Finite-element modeling was employed to explain how the environment in the vicinity of the driven bead can impact 1P active micro-rheology.

Broader impacts: The 2P-active micro-rheology technique developed in this project offers several advantages over existing micro-rheology approaches and can be applied to study a number of polymeric systems. Advancement in understanding the modulation of collagen network mechanics by matrix molecules can be applied to interpret tissue behavior in-vivo and to design biomaterials. This research brought together four investigators into a multi-disciplinary team encompassing experimental and computational approaches in physics, biology and materials science. Two PhD graduate students and six undergraduates were trained in this multi-disciplinary environment. Middle school girls were also provided an opportunity to participate in a hands-on workshop to measure persistence length.
